div.p: 1. The general designation for the spirits is guǐ shén 鬼神, and for the higher and lower spirits of Heaven and Earth it is shén qí 神祇.
2. Guǐ 鬼 is very often a spirit of the deceased (See GHOST), but the word can also refer to nature spirits of all kinds.
3. Shén 神 refers to the ethereal supernatural spirits of all kinds, primarily associated with heaven, but the word also refers to a righteous person who turns into such a spirit after death.
4. Míng shén 明神 refers to the luminous elevated higher spirits, and it is significant that there are not míng guǐ 明鬼.
5. Qí 祇 refers to the spirits of the earth.
6. Yāo 妖 are wicked spirits, and jiān 姦 can be used in the same sense. See DEVIL.

7. Xiān 仙 refers to ethereal divinised creatures of any kind, typically to those who have attained an eternal life on earth, and it is striking that the word gained currency first in Eastern Han times, and that the word is very common in the verbal meaning "become an immortal", whereas guǐ 鬼 is very rarely so used.
神，天神，天地萬物的創造者和主宰者；亦可泛指神靈，早於靈、祇、鬼的泛指。
靈，天神；有時泛指神靈，多見於上古楚國方言，漢代起普遍泛指神靈。
祇，地神；也可泛指神靈，其用較少見。
鬼，人死後的神靈，多指家族祖先神；漢代起已可泛指萬物（不包括天地）之精靈，不限於人神。
rough draft to BEGIN TO identify synonym group members for analysis, based on CL etc. 18.11.2003. CH ／

Woerterbuch der Philosophie. Neue Beitraege zu einer Kritik der Sprache

note.p: 1. It is most striking that xia1n 仙 is so predominant in the meaning "become an immortal", whereas she2n 神 only occasionally has a comparable meaning.

bibl.title: Bibliographisches Handbuch zur Sprachinhaltsforschung. Teil II. Systematischer Teil. B. Ordnung nach Sinnbezirken (mit einem alphabetischen Begriffsschluessel): Der Mensch und seine Welt im Spiegel der Sprachforschung

entry.def: Xiān 仙 refers to ethereal divinised creatures of any kind, typically to those who have attained an eternal life on earth, and it is striking that the word gained currency first in Eastern Han times, and that the word is very common in the verbal meaning "become an immortal", whereas guǐ 鬼 is very rarely so used.

Xiān 仙 refers to ethereal divinised creatures of any kind, typically to those who have attained an eternal life on earth, and it is striking that the word gained currency first in Eastern Han times, and that the word is very common in the verbal meaning "become an immortal", whereas guǐ 鬼 is very rarely so used.

sense.def: immortals [By the way: is this used to refer to a single definite immortal?]
become an immortal 仙者 "one who has become an immortal"
the art of immortality; the way of immortality
god of the soil, spirits of the soil

entry.def: Yāo 妖 are wicked spirits, and jiān 姦 can be used in the same sense. See DEVIL.
Yāo 妖 are wicked spirits, and jiān 姦 can be used in the same sense. See DEVIL.

sense.def: Mountain deity (David N. Keightley transcribes this chracter with a goat's horns on the top.)
the god of the (altar of) the earth

entry.def: Qí 祇 refers to the spirits of the earth.
Shén 神refers to the ethereal supernatural spirits of all kinds, primarily associated with heaven, but the word also refers to a righteous person who turns into such a spirit after death.

sense.def: the spirits; the divine creatures; divinity, spirit (typically belonging to or stemming from Heaven)
deity/deities of the N (including rivers, mountains and the like)
the soul of a deceased person (especially insofar as it is endowed with a supernatural efficacy); spirit; deity
(God of) Storms [Keightley: The Shang conceived of the wind, like so many other naturalphenomena, both beneficial and harmful, as under the command ofDi, the High God.

entry.def: Guǐ 鬼 is very often a spirit of the deceased (See GHOST), but the word can also refer to nature spirits of all kinds.

sense.def: generally: the spirits and ghosts 鬼神
like a ghost, like a spirit
ghosts in a number of V
female soul (which returns to Earth after death)
benign spirit able to drive out high fevers
BUDDH: kind of demons, in the Buddhist tradition regarded as one of the eight kind of beings said to protect the Buddhist teaching; SANSKRIT yakṣa

entry.def: Míng shén 明神 refers to the luminous elevated higher spirits, and it is significant that there are not míng guǐ 明鬼.

sense.def: gods of the land and grain (of the lexically determinate subject, i.e. the main subject of the clause)
the art of becoming immortal (perhaps one might analyse this as NPab(adN)
realm of the spirits; the deities, the gods; sometimes explicitly: the gods of Heaven and Earth 天地之神明
the higher realm of the purified spiritual world (of the deities, also as represented in the mind of the enlightened person); spiritual magic
regard as invested with higher spiritual power

entry.def: The general designation for the spirits is guǐ shén 鬼神, and for the higher and lower spirits of Heaven and Earth it is shén qí 神祇.

sense.def: ghost or spirit of any kind 狀似鬼神； 鬼神無形體
the ghosts and spirits (always in the plural, occasionally generic)
Mistress of N, Lord of N
